title: The Good Shepherd
shortSummary: Ezekiel 34 addresses the failure of Israel's leaders, depicted as shepherds, who neglected and exploited God's people. God declares judgment on these shepherds and promises to personally seek, gather, and care for His scattered flock through a future shepherd, identified as David, symbolizing the Messiah. This chapter highlights God's care, justice, and covenant faithfulness toward His people.
timeline: c. 593 BC - During the Babylonian exile, Ezekiel prophesies to the exiled Israelites

keyCharacters.name: Shepherds of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The leaders of Israel who are condemned for selfishness and neglect of God's people.

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: Referred to as God's servant and the future shepherd who will care for Israel, symbolizing the Messiah.

keyCharacters.name: The Flock (Israel)
keyCharacters.description: God's people, scattered and vulnerable due to the failure of their leaders.

definitions.definition: A leader or ruler responsible for guiding and caring for the people, often used metaphorically for kings or spiritual leaders.
A phrase describing those who are prosperous and powerful, often at the expense of the weak.
An enclosure or shelter for sheep; metaphorically, a place of safety and care for God's people.
A divine promise of lasting peace and security between God and His people.

outline.heading: Condemnation of Israel’s Shepherds
outline.description: God condemns the leaders of Israel for selfishness and neglect, accusing them of feeding themselves rather than the flock. Their failure caused the sheep to scatter and become vulnerable.

outline.heading: God’s Promise to Shepherd His People
outline.description: God declares His intention to personally seek out, gather, and care for His scattered sheep, restoring the lost and healing the broken.

outline.heading: Judgment Among the Flock
outline.description: God will judge between the strong and the weak within the flock, ensuring justice and protection for the vulnerable.

outline.heading: The Coming Shepherd: David
outline.description: God promises to set up one shepherd, His servant David, who will feed and rule the people, signifying the coming Messiah.

outline.heading: Blessings of Restoration and Security
outline.description: God promises a covenant of peace, protection from enemies, abundant provision, and a restored relationship with His people.

application: Leaders in the church and community must shepherd with selflessness, prioritizing the spiritual welfare of those entrusted to them.
Believers can trust in God’s personal care and guidance, especially when feeling lost or scattered.
Christ, the Good Shepherd, fulfills God’s promise to care for His people perfectly; Christians should follow His example and find security in Him.
Pray for God’s justice to prevail among His people and for the restoration of those who are weak or broken.

keyVerses.text: For thus saith the Lord GOD; Behold, I, even I, will both search my sheep, and seek them out.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God's personal commitment to seek and care for His people, emphasizing His role as the true shepherd.

keyVerses.text: And I will set up one shepherd over them, and he shall feed them, even my servant David; he shall feed them, and he shall be their shepherd.
keyVerses.significance: This prophecy points to the Messiah, Jesus Christ, who will faithfully shepherd and lead God's people.

keyVerses.text: I will seek that which was lost, and bring again that which was driven away, and will bind up that which was broken, and will strengthen that which was sick: but I will destroy the fat and the strong; I will feed them with judgment.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's restorative care for the weak and His righteous judgment against the corrupt.
